Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Georgetown University REU Site for Materials Physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Georgetown University REU in Materials Physics

Each year, nine undergraduates from diverse backgrounds and a broad spectrum of institutions will be recruited for a 10-week summer research experience in materials physics at Georgetown University. Students will engage in experimental, computational, and theoretical research projects in nanoscale physics, soft matter, device physics, active matter, biophysics, and cold-atom systems.

Taking advantage of Georgetown's location in the nation's capital, students will be exposed to the role of science, particularly materials research, in public policy. These activities build on Georgetown?s existing programs designed to engage undergraduate science majors directly with the government on issues of national importance, and will help build an understanding of the connection between scientific research and the world outside of the laboratory. Students will also participate in a variety of professional development activities, many of which will be held jointly with the REU program in the Georgetown Chemistry Department.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project “Georgetown University REU Site for Materials Physics” provided an intensive summer research experience for 26 undergraduate students majoring in Physics and related fields. The program ran for 10 weeks during the summers of 2010, 2011. and 2013. Students from diverse backgrounds and a broad spectrum of institutions participated in experimental, computational, and theoretical research projects in nanoscale physics, soft matter, device physics, biophysics, and cold-atom systems.  The research projects allowed students to work independently to formulate testable hypotheses, design and execute experiments, and analyze and interpret the results. At the same time, the students interacted regularly with graduate students, post-docs, and faculty mentors to develop their technical and intellectual skills and to gain an appreciation for the role of teamwork in scientific research. Each week, there were additional enrichment activities that included professional development workshops on topics such as scientific writing, presentation skills, professional ethics, and careers in science.

In addition, the program took advantage of our location in the nation’s capital to expose students to the role of science, particularly materials research, in public policy. Students were provided with an overview of the interaction between science and policy at the federal level and participated in seminars and panels led by Ph.D. scientists working in the legislative or regulatory arena, such as on congressional staffs, in regulatory agencies, and in non-governmental organizations involved in science policy.  Each summer students were also taken on a one day visit to the U.S. Capitol, where they were given briefings by congressional staff describing the process of creating legislation and the science policy issues connected to pending legislation. Students were encouraged to follow up these briefings by attending committee hearings or meeting with congressional staff from their home districts. 

On our surveys of students at the end of the program, many participants credited the REU experience with introducing them to materials physics and helping them develop a more sophisticated understanding of the role of science and scientists in public policy. A number of participants also noted that the experience opened their eyes to the collaborative nature of research and to the fact that research does not always proceed in a straight-line fashion.  Of the 26 participants, 12 are currently pursuing STEM Ph.D.s in physics, materials science, mechanical engineering, aerospace engineering, electrical engineering, and computational biology, and 2 are in STEM M.S. programs.  In addition, 5 are working in STEM jobs in industry or government labs (e.g., Honda, Microsoft, Naval Submarine Base), and some of those plan to go to graduate school after working for a few years. Two participants are working in science education.
